METS:xmlData.entity:description: Obnovo poljske države po prvi svetovni vojni so spremljali spopadi za meje med Drugo poljsko republiko in sosednjimi državami. Po naslednji obnovi neodvisnosti Poljske leta 1989 ni prišlo do takih fizičnih spopadov. Vseeno pa so po padcu komunizma poljski in nemški politiki razpravljali o zahodni poljski meji. Odločnih zahtev po hitrem priznanju črte Odra-Nisa za poljsko-nemško mejo, ki jih je ministrski predsednik Mazowiecki leta 1990 postavil Kohlovi vladi, ni mogoče obravnavati zgolj kot varnostno vprašanje. Njegove izjave so prispevale k oblikovanju nove nacionalne identitete. Ustvarila se je dihotomija med "nami" (Poljaki in njihovim "tradicionalnim" statusom žrtve) in "njimi" (Nemci kot tradicionalnimi agresorji). Pri procesu ustvarjanja novih nacionalnih identitet in spominov v nekdanjih socialističnih in komunističnih državah v Srednjevzhodni in Jugovzhodni Evropi je zanimiva metoda "selektivne izbire", ki so jo uporabljali politiki. Poljska izstopa kot izrazit primer. Na eni strani se preambula ustave Republike Poljske iz leta 1997 sklicuje na Prvo in Drugo poljsko republiko ter "več kot tisočletno dediščino" države, na drugi strani pa je na predstave o tem, kateri del Evrope naj bi štel za poljsko ozemlje, vplival Potsdamski sporazum, in ne meje, za katere so se poljske sile bojevale po koncu prve svetovne vojne. Tukaj pridejo do izraza prednosti, ki jih politikom omogoča umetni značaj upravnih meja.

The recreation of the Polish state in the aftermath of WWI was accompanied by border wars between the Second Polish Republic and its neighbouring states. After the next renewed independence of Poland, in 1989, no such physical wars did break out. Nevertheless, Poland’s western border was discussed by Polish and German politicians from the collapse of Communism onwards. The determinedness with which Prime Minister Mazowiecki claimed the necessity of a quick acknowledgement by the Kohl administration of the Oder­Neisse line as the Polish­German border in 1990, cannot be considered as just an issue of security. His statements contributed to the construction of a new national identity. A dichotomy between ‘us’ (Poles and their ‘traditional’ status as victims) and ‘them’ (Germans as traditional aggressors) was created. What is interesting about the process of constructing new national identities and memories in former socialist and communist states in East­Central and Southeast Europe, is the method of ‘cherry picking’ used by politicians. The Polish case is a striking example. On the one hand, the preamble of the 1997 Constitution of the Republic of Poland contains references to the First and Second Polish Republic and the country’s “over one thousand years’ heritage”, on the other, notions about which part of Europe should be considered as Polish soil was influenced by the Potsdam Agreement instead of borders on which wars had been fought by Polish forces in the aftermath of WWI. It is here that the benefits for politicians of the artificiality of administrative borders comes to the fore. The politics of memory by at least some governments of the Third Polish Republic are an example of the interconnectedness between nationalism and the concept of administrative legacy. The possibility to decide on whether to use this legacy, is an important tool to execute nationalist politics.
